did.abstract: Physicist, professor of physics at the University of Michigan and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology; correspondence, lectures and speeches, publications, notebooks, research papers, and topical files.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The collection was acquired on September 15, 1993, from Mrs. Else R. Uhlenbeck (Donor No. 8182). Additional papers came to the library in 1998. A small accession was received in 2002.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.

userestrict.p: Copyright has been transferred to the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: item, folder title, box no., George Uhlenbeck Papers, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: George Eugène Uhlenbeck was born on 6 December 1900, in Batavia, Java, Dutch East Indies [now Jakarta, Indonesia]. In 1907 the family returned to the Netherlands, settling permanently in the Hague.

Uhlenbeck showed an early, self-directed interest in physics, attracting the attention of his high school physics instructor. Because a Dutch law required entering university students to have training in Latin and Greek, Uhlenbeck enrolled as an engineering student at the Technische Hogeschool at Delft in September 1918. A propitious change in the law allowed him, in January 1919, to begin studies in physics and mathematics at the University of Leiden.

In 1920, Uhlenbeck began attending seminars at Leiden given by the physicist Paul Ehrenfest, who was to become his primary scientific mentor. From 1922 to 1925 he spent summers in Holland and the remainder of the year in Rome, serving as tutor for the son of J. H. van Royen, the Dutch ambassador there. While in Rome he attended mathematics courses given by Enriques, Levi-Civita, and Volterra. In 1923 he met Enrico Fermi and established a contact between Ehrenfest and Fermi that, according to Abraham Pais in an article on Uhlenbeck in the December 1989 Physics Today, proved critical to Fermi's career.

Uhlenbeck became interested in Dutch cultural history and his first publication, written in Rome, was a historical piece on Johannes Heckius. Upon his return to Holland in 1925, Uhlenbeck considered becoming a historian, establishing contact at Leiden with the influential medieval historian Johan Huizinga.

At Ehrenfest's urging, Uhlenbeck teamed up with another graduate student, Samuel Goudsmit, in the fall of 1925, a collaboration which invigorated his interest in physics. Their work in the decoding of atomic spectra led rapidly to a discovery of electron spin, which proved to be an essential building block for modern particle physics and thrust the young graduate student into the scientific spotlight.

In 1925 Uhlenbeck immigrated to the United States to join the faculty at the University of Michigan. He returned to the Netherlands from 1935 to 1939 to teach the first courses ever offered in nuclear physics at the University of Utrecht. The decade of the 1940s saw Uhlenbeck back in the United States, dividing his time between teaching responsibilities at Michigan and, from 1942 to 1945, directing classified radar research at the Radiation Laboratory, Massachusetts Institute of Technology. Uhlenbeck remained an important figure in physics at the University of Michigan until his 1960 move to Rockefeller University, from which he retired in 1974.

Uhlenbeck's ties with the Netherlands remained strong throughout his career. In 1954 he became the first Lorentz Visiting Professor of Physics at the University of Leiden; additionally, in 1963, he was named the first Van der Waals Visiting Professor of Theoretical Physics at the University of Amsterdam. In 1977 the Dutch government honored him by making him a Commander of the Order of Orange-Nassau, the highest non-military honor it can give to non-citizens.

Along with numerous honorary degrees, Uhlenbeck was awarded several medals in recognition of his contributions to the field of theoretical physics: the Max Planck medal in 1964, the Lorentz medal in 1970, and the National Medal of Science in 1977. George Eugène Uhlenbeck died on 31 October 1988, in Boulder, Colorado.

scopecontent.p: The George Uhlenbeck papers, measuring 7 linear feet span the years 1918 to 1982, with the bulk covering the period 1925 to 1970. The papers are arranged in six series: Correspondence, Lectures and Speeches, Publications, Notebooks and Exams, Research Papers, and Topical. They document a lengthy career as both a physicist of international renown and an active teacher and collaborator.

controlaccess.head: Subjects:
controlaccess.subject: National socialism and science.
Nuclear physics.
Physics.
controlaccess.corpname: University of Michigan. Dept. of Physics.

scopecontent.p: The Correspondence series, containing both incoming and outgoing correspondence, is divided into two subseries: Chronological and Alphabetical.

The first subseries is arranged chronologically and covers the period 1926 to 1981. The bulk of this correspondence includes technical discussions of ongoing research in nuclear physics with colleagues from around the world, evaluations of the work of students, and correspondence regarding guest lectureships and visiting professorships. This subseries provides valuable insight into the development of nuclear physics in the middle of the 20th century, as well as the academic obligations of a university faculty member. Additionally, there are letters from the decades of the 1930s and 1940s to and from European scientists assessing the effects of the rise of National Socialism in Germany on European physics. The bulk of the earlier correspondence is in Dutch and German.

The second subseries of the Correspondence series is arranged alphabetically by the correspondent. These include Uhlenbeck's mentor, Paul Ehrenfest, his first collaborator, Samuel Goudsmit, and other significant collaborators and figures in physics with whom Uhlenbeck carried on extensive communication. Additionally, there is extensive documentation of Uhlenbeck's role as an editor and reviewer for the publications of both the American Physical Society and the American Institute of Physics.

did.unittitle: American Institute of Physics, editor (Joseph E. Mayer) 1938-1947
American Physical Society, editors (John T. Tate, E.L. Hill, and J.W. Buchta) 1931-1947

scopecontent.p: Lectures and Speeches document Uhlenbeck's rich career as an orator. These are arranged by title, where a title is given, or according to the event at which he spoke. A predominating theme in many of Uhlenbeck's presentations is the importance of understanding the history of physics and the need for effective collaboration within the field.

did.unittitle: "Die entropy der welt ist constant": temperature and heat lecture undated
Electron spin, 50th anniversary of discovery by Uhlenbeck and Goudsmit 1976
Is there a direction in time? 1956-1974
Principles of thermodynamics and statistical mechanics 1973
Some fundamental problems in statistical physics
Summarizing remarks at Copenhagen Physics Conference 1967

scopecontent.p: The Notebooks and Exams series documents Uhlenbeck's contribution in physics education. The exams covers the 1940s and 1950s, in which Uhlenbeck was a professor at the University of Michigan. The content of the notebooks is technical, containing chiefly calculations and notes for courses on statistical and quantum mechanics, kinetic theory of matter, and nuclear physics.

did.unittitle: Miscellaneous notes taken by students undated

scopecontent.p: The Publications series is also divided into two subseries. The first contains Uhlenbeck's articles, arranged chronologically by his wife with a handwritten inventory of each folder's contents. The second subseries contains a few of Uhlenbeck's monographs, also arranged chronologically by the date of publication. The researcher should note that there is additional published material by George Uhlenbeck in the library's collection and should consult the printed works card catalog for titles.

did.unittitle: Technical Reports (Engineering Research Institute, U. of M.), 1954-1956

scopecontent.p: Research Papers are papers produced by Uhlenbeck at universities and under contract with the United States government and private agencies rather than published. They are arranged by title.

did.unittitle: Basis of Functional Assumptions in the Theory of the Boltzmann Equation undated
Contributions to Non-Equilibrium Thermodynamics I & II 1969
Kinetic Theory of Phenomena in Dense Gases 1958
On the Propagation of Sound in Monatomic Gases 1948
On the Transport Phenomena in Rarefied Gases 1948
Possible Origins of the Quantized Vortices in He2 1972
Some Historical and Critical Remarks about the Theory of Phase Transition undated
Some Problems in the Kinetic Theory of Dilute Gases undated
Thermodynamic Equilibrium of Rotating Superfluids undated
Transport Phenomena in Very Dilute Gases 1949

scopecontent.p: The Topical series contains informally gathered folders of materials tagged by Uhlenbeck with various titles. Most are topics in the field of physics, and appear to be Uhlenbeck's work in progress that he might have intended to develop into articles or speeches. Others include papers from organizations Uhlenbeck contracted his services to, such as the Navy and the Rand Corporation. In addition, this series contains records of the Joint Committee of American Philosophical Society and American Physical Society, whose main purpose was to document the history of theoretical physics in the twentieth century.

did.unittitle: Bibliography prepared by George W. Ford of Uhlenbeck writings 1924-1980
Brownian Motion in a Knudsen Gas 1976
International Congress on Theoretical Physics September 17-21, 1956
Joint Committee of American Philosophical Society and American Physical Society
History of Theoretical Physics in the Twentieth Century 1960-1961
